1337        for(int i = 0; i < maps.length; i++)
1338        {
1339            for (int x = 0; x < width && x < maps[i].length; x++) {
1340                for (int y = 0; y < height && y < maps[i][x].length; y++) {
1341                    if(losMap[x][y] > 0.0001) {
1342                        map[x][y] += maps[i][x][y];
1343                    }
1344                }
1345            }
1346        }
1347        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1348            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1349                if(map[x][y] > 1.0) map[x][y] = 1.0;
1350            }
1351        }
1352
1353        return map;
1354    }
1355    /**
1356     * Adds together multiple FOV maps, but only adds to a position if it is visible in the given LOS map. Useful if
1357     * you want distant lighting to be visible only if the player has line-of-sight to a lit cell. Typically the LOS map
1358     * is calculated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}, using the same resistance map used to
1359     * calculate the FOV maps. Clamps the highest value for any single position at 1.0.
1360     * @param losMap an LOS map such as one generated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}
1361     * @param basis an existing 2D double array that should have matching width and height to losMap; will be modified
1362     * @param maps an array or vararg of 2D double arrays, each usually returned by calculateFOV()
1363     * @return the sum of all the 2D double arrays in maps where a cell was visible in losMap
1364     */
1365    public static double[][] mixVisibleFOVsInto(double[][] losMap, double[][] basis, double[][]... maps)
1366
1367    {
1368        if(losMap == null || losMap.length <= 0 || losMap[0].length <= 0)
1369            return addFOVsInto(basis, maps);
1370        final int width = losMap.length, height = losMap[0].length;
1371        double[][] map = new double[width][height];
1372        if(maps == null || maps.length == 0)
1373            return map;
1374        for(int i = 0; i < maps.length; i++)
1375        {
1376            for (int x = 0; x < width && x < maps[i].length; x++) {
1377                for (int y = 0; y < height && y < maps[i][x].length; y++) {
1378                    if(losMap[x][y] > 0.0001) {
1379                        map[x][y] += maps[i][x][y];
1380                    }
1381                }
1382            }
1383        }
1384        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1385            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1386                if(map[x][y] > 1.0) map[x][y] = 1.0;
1387            }
1388        }
1389        return map;
1390    }
1391
1392    /**
1393     * Adds together multiple FOV maps, but only adds to a position if it is visible in the given LOS map. Useful if
1394     * you want distant lighting to be visible only if the player has line-of-sight to a lit cell. Typically the LOS map
1395     * is calculated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}, using the same resistance map used to
1396     * calculate the FOV maps. Clamps the highest value for any single position at 1.0.
1397     * @param losMap an LOS map such as one generated by {@link #reuseLOS(double[][], double[][], int, int)}
1398     * @param maps an Iterable of 2D double arrays, each usually returned by calculateFOV()
1399     * @return the sum of all the 2D double arrays in maps where a cell was visible in losMap
1400     */
1401    public static double[][] mixVisibleFOVs(double[][] losMap, Iterable<double[][]> maps)
1402    {
1403        if(losMap == null || losMap.length == 0)
1404            return addFOVs(maps);
1405        final int width = losMap.length, height = losMap[0].length;
1406        double[][] map = new double[width][height];
1407        if(maps == null)
1408            return map;
1409        for (double[][] map1 : maps) {
1410            for (int x = 0; x < width && x < map1.length; x++) {
1411                for (int y = 0; y < height && y < map1[x].length; y++) {
1412                    if (losMap[x][y] > 0.0001) {
1413                        map[x][y] += map1[x][y];
1414                        if (map[x][y] > 1.0) map[x][y] = 1.0;
1415                    }
1416                }
1417            }
1418        }
1419        return map;
1420    }
1421
1422    /**
1423     * Calculates what cells are visible from (startX,startY) using the given resistanceMap; this can be given to
1424     * mixVisibleFOVs() to limit extra light sources to those visible from the starting point. Just like calling
1425     * calculateFOV(), this creates a new double[][]; there doesn't appear to be a way to work with Ripple FOV and avoid
1426     * needing an empty double[][] every time, since it uses previously-placed light to determine how it should spread.
1427     * @param resistanceMap the grid of cells to calculate on; the kind made by {@link #generateResistances(char[][])}
1428     * @param startX the center of the LOS map; typically the player's x-position
1429     * @param startY the center of the LOS map; typically the player's y-position
1430     * @return an LOS map with the given starting point
1431     */
1432    public double[][] calculateLOSMap(double[][] resistanceMap, int startX, int startY)
1433    {
1434        if(resistanceMap == null || resistanceMap.length <= 0  || resistanceMap[0].length <= 0)
1435            return new double[0][0];
1436
1437        int width = resistanceMap.length;
1438        int height = resistanceMap[0].length;
1439        double rad = width + height;
1440        double decay = 1.0 / rad;
1441
1442        initializeLightMap(width, height);
1443        light[startX][startY] = 1;//make the starting space full power
1444
1445        switch (type) {
1446            case RIPPLE:
1447            case RIPPLE_LOOSE:
1448            case RIPPLE_TIGHT:
1449            case RIPPLE_VERY_LOOSE:
1450                initializeNearLight(width, height);
1451                doRippleFOV(light, rippleValue(type), startX, startY, decay, rad, resistanceMap, nearLight, Radius.SQUARE);
1452                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1453                    for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1454                        if(light[x][y] > 0.0001)
1455                            light[x][y] = 1.0;
1456                    }
1457                }
1458                break;
1459            default:
1460                for (Direction d : Direction.DIAGONALS) {
1461                    shadowCastBinary(1, 1.0, 0.0, 0, d.deltaX, d.deltaY, 0, rad, startX, startY, decay, light, resistanceMap, Radius.SQUARE, 0, 0, width, height);
1462                    shadowCastBinary(1, 1.0, 0.0, d.deltaX, 0, 0, d.deltaY, rad, startX, startY, decay, light, resistanceMap, Radius.SQUARE, 0, 0, width, height);
1463                }
1464                break;
1465        }
1466        return light;
1467    }
1468
1469
1470
1471    /**
1472     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with most of the methods in FOV, like
1473     * {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)}. It expects any doors to be represented by '+' if
1474     * closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])}), any walls to
1475     * be '#' or box drawing characters, and it doesn't care what other chars are used (only doors, including open ones,
1476     * and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance by default).
1477     *
1478     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1479     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class, with clear cells assigned 0.0 and blocked ones 1.0
1480     */
1481    public static double[][] generateResistances(char[][] map) {
1482        int width = map.length;
1483        int height = map[0].length;
1484        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
1485        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
1486            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
1487                switch (map[i][j]) {
1488                    case '\1':
1489                    case '├':
1490                    case '┤':
1491                    case '┴':
1492                    case '┬':
1493                    case '┌':
1494                    case '┐':
1495                    case '└':
1496                    case '┘':
1497                    case '│':
1498                    case '─':
1499                    case '┼':
1500                    case '#':
1501                        portion[i][j] = 1.0;
1502                        break;
1503                    case '/':
1504                    case '"':
1505                        portion[i][j] = 0.15;
1506                        break;
1507                    case '+':
1508                        portion[i][j] = 0.95;
1509                        break;
1510                    case '.':
1511                    case ',':
1512                    case '~':
1513                    case '^':
1514                    default:
1515                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
1516                }
1517            }
1518        }
1519        return portion;
1520    }
1521
1522    /**
1523     * Given a char[][] for the map that should use box drawing characters (as produced by
1524     * {@link DungeonUtility#hashesToLines(char[][], boolean)}), produces a double[][] with triple width and triple
1525     * height that can be used with FOV methods like {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)} in
1526     * classes that use subcell lighting. Importantly, this only considers a "thin line" of wall to be blocking
1527     * (matching the box drawing character), instead of the whole 3x3 area. This expects any doors to be represented by
1528     * '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])}), thick
1529     * vegetation or other concealing obstructions to be '"', any normal walls to be box drawing characters, any cells
1530     * that block all subcells to be '#', and it doesn't care what other chars are used (only doors, including open
1531     * ones, vegetation, and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance normally).
1532     *
1533     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1534     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class and subcell lighting, with triple width/height
1535     */
1536    public static double[][] generateResistances3x3(char[][] map) {
1537        int width = map.length;
1538        int height = map[0].length;
1539        double[][] portion = new double[width * 3][height * 3];
1540        for (int i = 0, x = 0; i < width; i++, x+=3) {
1541            for (int j = 0, y = 0; j < height; j++, y+=3) {
1542                switch (map[i][j]) {
1543                    case '\1':
1544                    case '#':
1545                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1546                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1547                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 1.0;
1548                        break;
1549                    case '├':
1550                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1551                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1552                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1553                        break;
1554                    case '┤':
1555                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1556                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1557                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1558                        break;
1559                    case '┴':
1560                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1561                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1562                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1563                        break;
1564                    case '┬':
1565                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1566                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1567                                /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1568                        break;
1569                    case '┌':
1570                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1571                        /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1572                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1573                        break;
1574                    case '┐':
1575                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1576                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1577                                /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1578                        break;
1579                    case '└':
1580                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1581                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1582                            /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1583                        break;
1584                    case '┘':
1585                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1586                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1587                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1588                        break;
1589                    case '│':
1590                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1591                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1592                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1593                        break;
1594                    case '─':
1595                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] = 1.0;
1596                        break;
1597                    case '╴':
1598                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = 1.0;
1599                        break;
1600                    case '╵':
1601                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1602                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/ 1.0;
1603                        break;
1604                    case '╶':
1605                        portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] = 1.0;
1606                        break;
1607                    case '╷':
1608                        /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1609                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1610                        break;
1611                    case '┼':
1612                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1613                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1614                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1615                        break;
1616                    case '/':
1617                    case '"':
1618                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1619                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1620                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 0.15;
1621                        break;
1622                    case '+':
1623                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1624                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1625                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 0.95;
1626                        break;
1627                }
1628            }
1629        }
1630        return portion;
1631    }
1632
1633    /**
1634     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with any FOV methods that expect a
1635     * resistance map (like {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)}), but does not treat
1636     * any cells as partly transparent, only fully-blocking or fully-permitting light. This is mainly useful if you
1637     * expect the FOV radius to be very high or (effectively) infinite, since anything less than complete blockage would
1638     * be passed through by infinite-radius FOV. This expects any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if
1639     * open (most door placement defaults to a mix of '+' and '/', so by calling
1640     * {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])} you can close all doors at the start), and any walls to be '#' or
1641     * box drawing characters. This will assign 1.0 resistance to walls and closed doors or 0.0 for any other cell.
1642     *
1643     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1644     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class, but with no partially transparent cells
1645     */
1646    public static double[][] generateSimpleResistances(char[][] map) {
1647        int width = map.length;
1648        int height = map[0].length;
1649        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
1650        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
1651            for (int j = 0; j < height; j++) {
1652                switch (map[i][j]) {
1653                    case '\1':
1654                    case '├':
1655                    case '┤':
1656                    case '┴':
1657                    case '┬':
1658                    case '┌':
1659                    case '┐':
1660                    case '└':
1661                    case '┘':
1662                    case '│':
1663                    case '─':
1664                    case '┼':
1665                    case '#':
1666                    case '+':
1667                        portion[i][j] = 1.0;
1668                        break;
1669                    default:
1670                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
1671                }
1672            }
1673        }
1674        return portion;
1675    }

1677    /**
1678     * Given a char[][] for the map that should use box drawing characters (as produced by
1679     * {@link DungeonUtility#hashesToLines(char[][], boolean)}), produces a double[][] with triple width and triple
1680     * height that can be used with FOV's methods that expect a resistance map (like
1681     * {@link #reuseFOV(double[][], double[][], int, int, double)}) in classes that use subcell lighting. This expects
1682     * any doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (most door placement defaults to a mix of '+' and
1683     * '/', so by calling {@link DungeonUtility#closeDoors(char[][])} you can close all doors at the start), any walls
1684     * to be box drawing characters, and any cells that block all subcells within their area to be '#'. This will assig
1685     * 1.0 resistance to walls and closed doors where a line of the box drawing char would block light, or 0.0 for an
1686     * other subcell.
1687     *
1688     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
1689     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class and subcell lighting, with triple width/height
1690     */
1691    public static double[][] generateSimpleResistances3x3(char[][] map) {
1692        int width = map.length;
1693        int height = map[0].length;
1694        double[][] portion = new double[width * 3][height * 3];
1695        for (int i = 0, x = 0; i < width; i++, x+=3) {
1696            for (int j = 0, y = 0; j < height; j++, y+=3) {
1697                switch (map[i][j]) {
1698                    case '\1':
1699                    case '#':
1700                    case '+':
1701                        portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =
1702                                portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1703                                        portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] = 1.0;
1704                        break;
1705                    case '├':
1706                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1707                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1708                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1709                        break;
1710                    case '┤':
1711                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1712                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1713                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1714                        break;
1715                    case '┴':
1716                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1717                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1718                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1719                        break;
1720                    case '┬':
1721                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1722                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1723                                /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1724                        break;
1725                    case '┌':
1726                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1727                        /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1728                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1729                        break;
1730                    case '┐':
1731                        /*portion[x][y] = portion[x+1][y] = portion[x+2][y] =*/
1732                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1733                                /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1734                        break;
1735                    case '└':
1736                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1737                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1738                            /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1739                        break;
1740                    case '┘':
1741                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1742                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1743                                    /*portion[x][y+2] = portion[x+1][y+2] = portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1744                        break;
1745                    case '│':
1746                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1747                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1748                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1749                        break;

1752                        break;
1753                    case '╴':
1754                        portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = 1.0;
1755                        break;
1756                    case '╵':
1757                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1758                            /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/ 1.0;
1759                        break;
1760                    case '╶':
1761                        portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] = 1.0;
1762                        break;
1763                    case '╷':
1764                        /*portion[x][y+1] =*/ portion[x+1][y+1] = /*portion[x+2][y+1] =*/
1765                            /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1766                        break;
1767                    case '┼':
1768                        /*portion[x][y] =*/ portion[x+1][y] = /*portion[x+2][y] =*/
1769                            portion[x][y+1] = portion[x+1][y+1] = portion[x+2][y+1] =
1770                                    /*portion[x][y+2] =*/ portion[x+1][y+2] = /*portion[x+2][y+2] =*/ 1.0;
1771                        break;
1772                }
1773            }
1774        }
1775        return portion;
1776    }
1777
1778    public static double[][] reuseBurstFOV(double[][] resistanceMap, double[][] light, int rippleLooseness, int x, int y, double radius, Radius radiusTechnique) {
1779        ArrayTools.fill(light, 0);
1780        light[x][y] = Math.min(1.0, radius);//make the starting space full power unless radius is tiny
1781        workingSet.clear();
1782        doBurstFOV(light, MathExtras.clamp(rippleLooseness, 1, 6), x, y, 1.0 / radius, radius, resistanceMap, radiusTechnique);
1783        return light;
1784    }
1785    private static void doBurstFOV(double[][] lightMap, int ripple, int x, int y, double decay, double radius, double[][] map, Radius radiusStrategy) {
1786        dq.clear();
1787        int width = lightMap.length;
1788        int height = lightMap[0].length;
1789        dq.offer(Coord.get(x, y));
1790        while (!dq.isEmpty()) {
1791            Coord p = dq.removeFirst();
1792            if (lightMap[p.x][p.y] <= 0 || workingSet.contains(p)) {
1793                continue;//no light to spread
1794            }
1795
1796            for (Direction dir : Direction.OUTWARDS) {
1797                int x2 = p.x + dir.deltaX;
1798                int y2 = p.y + dir.deltaY;
1799                if (x2 < 0 || x2 >= width || y2 < 0 || y2 >= height //out of bounds
1800                        || radiusStrategy.radius(x, y, x2, y2) > radius) {
1801                    continue;
1802                }
1803
1804                double surroundingLight = doBurstLight(x2, y2, ripple, x, y, decay, lightMap, map, radiusStrategy);
1805                if (lightMap[x2][y2] < surroundingLight) {
1806                    if (map[x2][y2] < 1) {//make sure it's not a wall
1807                        dq.offer(Coord.get(x2, y2));//redo neighbors since this one's light changed
1808                    }
1809                    lightMap[x2][y2] = surroundingLight;
1810
1811                }
1812            }
1813        }
1814    }
1815    private static double doBurstLight(int x, int y, int rippleNeighbors, int startx, int starty, double decay, double[][] lightMap, double[][] map, Radius radiusStrategy) {
1816        if (x == startx && y == starty) {
1817            return 1;
1818        }
1819        int width = lightMap.length;
1820        int height = lightMap[0].length;
1821        neighbors.clear();
1822        double tmpDistance = 0, testDistance;
1823        Coord c;
1824        for (Direction di : Direction.OUTWARDS) {
1825            int x2 = x + di.deltaX;
1826            int y2 = y + di.deltaY;
1827            if (x2 >= 0 && x2 < width && y2 >= 0 && y2 < height) {
1828                tmpDistance = radiusStrategy.radius(startx, starty, x2, y2);
1829                int idx = 0;
1830                for(int i = 0; i < neighbors.size() && i <= rippleNeighbors; i++)
1831                {
1832                    c = neighbors.get(i);
1833                    testDistance = radiusStrategy.radius(startx, starty, c.x, c.y);
1834                    if(tmpDistance >= testDistance) {
1835                        idx++;
1836                    }
1837                }
1838                neighbors.add(idx, Coord.get(x2, y2));
1839            }
1840        }
1841
1842        if (neighbors.isEmpty()) {
1843            return 0;
1844        }
1845        int max = Math.min(neighbors.size(), rippleNeighbors);
1846        double light = 0;
1847        int lit = 0, indirects = 0;
1848        for (int i = 0; i < max; i++) {
1849            Coord p = neighbors.get(i);
1850            if (lightMap[p.x][p.y] > 0) {
1851                lit++;
1852                if (workingSet.contains(p)) {
1853                    indirects++;
1854                }
1855                light = Math.max(light, lightMap[p.x][p.y]
1856                        - radiusStrategy.radius(x, y, p.x, p.y) * decay - map[p.x][p.y]);
1857            }
1858        }
1859
1860        if (map[x][y] >= 1 || indirects >= lit) {
1861            workingSet.add(Coord.get(x, y));
1862        }
1863        return light;
1864    }
1865
1866
1867}
